trial_identification.scientifictitle: A longitudinal Interpersonal Psycho-Therapeutic group treatment targeting parental interpersonal problems to improve mood and general health.

conditions.healthcondition: Depression and Interpersonal problems (loss & grief, interpersonal disputes, social isolation, role transitions).

interventions.interventions:
A longitudianal Interpersonal Psycho-Therapy program targeting mild to moderate parental mental health problems.
Treatment aims to help parents adjust to a new life role and better manage the difficulties that arise from parenting. It is conducted in a group and runs for 3 hours per week over a six week period.
The program does not assume that all parenting issues are solely caused from interpersonal problems. However, a dynamic interplay occurs between interpersonal, biological and personality factors.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
Parental psychosocial functioning.
Measured by the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS: Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), the General Health Questionaire and the Abbreviated Dyadic Adjustment Scale (ADAS: Shapley & Rogers, 1984).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be taken a baseline (just before), at the end (week 6) and 3 mths post treatment.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
Social adjustment.
Measured by the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS: Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), the General Health Questionaire and the Abbreviated Dyadic Adjustment Scale (ADAS: Shapley & Rogers, 1984).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be taken a baseline (just before), at the end (week 6) and 3 mths post treatment.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
General health.
Measured by the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS: Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), the General Health Questionaire and the Abbreviated Dyadic Adjustment Scale (ADAS: Shapley & Rogers, 1984).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be taken a baseline (just before), at the end (week 6) and 3 mths post treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1) Increased positive parental behaviours will be measures by the Parent Problem Checklist (PPC: Dadds & Powell, 1991), the Parenting Scale (PS: Arnold, OLeary, Wolff & Acker, 1993) and the Parenting Sense of Competence Scale (PSOC: Gibaud & Wallston, 1978.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be taken a baseline (just before), at the end (week 6) and 3 mths post treatment.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2) Decreased child behaviour problems will be measured by the Eyberg Child Behaviour Inventory (ECBI: Eyberg & Pincus, 1998).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be taken a baseline (just before), at the end (week 6) and 3 mths post treatment.
Measured by a satisfaction questionnaire issued at the end (week 6) and at 3 mth post treatment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1) are parents with children at home, 2) live in the Gold Coast Health Service District, 3) report mild to moderate mental health problems ie depresion, interpersoanl problems, loss and grief.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Have current psychotic symptoms, have severe substance abuse, do not have children at home and if they live outside the Gold Coast Health Service District .

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The purpose of the programme is to investigate whether parents improve their psychological and social functioning after completion of a Group Interpersonal Psychotherapy Program.
It is thought that participation will improve parents psychosocial functioning, social adjustment and general health and this will result in an increase in the amount/quality of positive parental behaviours they implement. Increased positive parenting behaviours will then produce a decrease in child behaviour problems.
